problem.prob_desc:
14. 두 자연수 $a,\ b$에 대하여 함수 $f(x)$는 $$f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x^3 - 6x + 1, & (x \le 2) \\ a(x - 2)(x - b) + 9, & (x > 2) \end{cases}$$이다. 실수 $t$에 대하여 함수 $y=f(x)$의 그래프와 직선 $y=t$가 만나는 점의 개수를 $g(t)$라 하자. $$g(k) + \lim_{t \to k^-} g(t) + \lim_{t \to k^+} g(t) = 9$$를 만족시키는 실수 $k$의 개수가 1이 되도록 하는 두 자연수 $a,\ b$의 순서쌍 $(a,\ b)$에  대하여 $a+b$의 최댓값은? [4점]
① 51 ② 52 ③ 53 ④ 54 ⑤ 55

claude-opus-4.5.title: 함수 분석 - 우측 부분 (x > 2)
claude-opus-4.5.body:
$f(x) = a(x-2)(x-b) + 9$ (단, $a, b$는 자연수)

$x = 2$에서의 우극한: $\lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x) = 9$

**연속성 확인**: $f(2) = 5 \neq 9$이므로 $x = 2$에서 불연속 (점프 불연속)

우측 부분은 $(x-2)(x-b)$의 이차함수:
- $b \leq 2$이면: $x > 2$에서 $(x-2)(x-b) > 0$이므로 $f(x) > 9$, 단조증가
- $b > 2$이면: 꼭짓점이 $x = \frac{2+b}{2}$에 있고, 최솟값은 $9 - a\cdot\frac{(b-2)^2}{4}$
[/STEP]

claude-opus-4.5.title: g(t)의 구조 파악
claude-opus-4.5.body:
수평선 $y = t$와 그래프의 교점 개수 $g(t)$:

좌측 부분($x \leq 2$)에서의 교점 개수:
- $t < -3$ 또는 $t > 5$: 0개
- $t = -3$ 또는 $t = 5$: 2개 (극값 또는 끝점)
- $-3 < t < 5$: 3개

우측 부분($x > 2$)에서의 교점 개수는 $a, b$에 따라 결정
[/STEP]

claude-opus-4.5.title: 조건 g(k) + 좌극한 + 우극한 = 9 분석
claude-opus-4.5.body:
$g(k) + \lim_{t \to k^-} g(t) + \lim_{t \to k^+} g(t) = 9$

이 조건이 성립하려면 $g(t)$가 $t = k$에서 불연속이어야 함.

**핵심 관찰**: $y = 5$와 $y = 9$가 중요한 임계값
- $t = 5$: 좌측에서 교점 개수가 3→2로 변화
- $t = 9$: 우측 부분의 시작점

$b > 2$인 경우, 우측 최솟값을 $m = 9 - a\cdot\frac{(b-2)^2}{4}$라 하면:
- $t = m$에서 우측 교점이 0→1→2로 변화
[/STEP]

gemini-3-pro.title: 조건 정리 및 함수 분석
gemini-3-pro.body:
주어진 함수 $f(x)$는 $x=2$를 기준으로 두 부분으로 나뉩니다.
1.  $x \le 2$일 때: $f_1(x) = 2x^3 - 6x + 1$
    *   미분: $f_1'(x) = 6x^2 - 6 = 6(x-1)(x+1)$
    *   극값: $x=-1$에서 극대, $x=1$에서 극소.
    *   함숫값:
        *   $f_1(-1) = -

gpt-5-codex.title: Study cubic branch
gpt-5-codex.body: For x≤2 we have f1(x)=2x^3−6x+1 with derivative 6(x−1)(x+1). Hence x=−1 gives a local maximum f1(−1)=5 and x=1 gives a local minimum f1(1)=−3. The range on (−∞,2] is (−∞,5], and the intersection counts with y=t are: g_L(t)=1 (t<−3), g_L(−3)=2, g_L(t)=3 (−3<t<5), g_L(5)=2, g_L(t)=0 (t>5).

gpt-5-codex.title: Study quadratic branch
gpt-5-codex.body: For x>2, f2(x)=a(x−2)(x−b)+9 has vertex at x=(b+2)/2 with minimum value y_min=9−a(b−2)^2/4. For b>2 (so the vertex lies in the domain), the intersection counts with y=t are: g_R(t)=0 (t<y_min), g_R(y_min)=1, g_R(t)=2 (y_min<t<9), g_R(9)=1 (x=b), and g_R(t)=1 (t>9).

gpt-5-codex.title: Avoid infinite solutions
gpt-5-codex.body: On the interval (−3,5) the cubic already contributes 3 intersections. If y_min>−3, there exists a subinterval where g_R(t)=0, yielding g(t)=3 on an interval and infinitely many solutions of g(k)+g(k^−)+g(k^+)=9. If y_min<−3, then (y_min,−3) provides g_L=1, g_R=2 ⇒ g=3, again giving infinitely many k. Thus the only way to avoid an interval with g=3 is y_min=−3, i.e. 9−a(b−2)^2/4=−3, which simplifies to a(b−2)^2=48.

gpt-5-codex.title: Solve for integer pairs
gpt-5-codex.body: Let d=b−2>0. Then a d^2=48. Squares dividing 48 are 1,4,16, giving (d,a)=(1,48),(2,12),(4,3) and hence candidate natural pairs (a,b)=(48,3),(12,4),(3,6).

gpt-5-codex.title: Verify unique k
gpt-5-codex.body: For any pair above, y_min=−3 and g_R(t)=2 for −3<t<9. Combining with g_L gives: g(t)=1 (t<−3), g(−3)=3, g(t)=5 (−3<t<5), g(5)=4, g(t)=2 (5<t<9), g(9)=1, g(t)=1 (t>9). At k=−3 we have g(k)=3, g(k^−)=1, g(k^+)=5 so the sum is 9. At k=5 it is 4+5+2=11, at k=9 it is 1+2+1=4, and on open intervals the sum is 3⋅1=3, 3⋅5=15, or 3⋅2=6. Thus exactly one real k (namely k=−3) satisfies the required equation.

gpt-5-codex.title: Maximize a plus b
gpt-5-codex.body: Compute a+b: 48+3=51, 12+4=16, 3+6=9. The maximum is 51, corresponding to option ①.

gpt-5.title: Analyze left branch f1
gpt-5.body: For x ≤ 2, f1(x)=2x^3−6x+1. f1'(x)=6(x^2−1), critical points at x=−1,1. Values: f1(−1)=5 (local max), f1(1)=−3 (local min), f1(2)=5. Hence, for the left branch L(t)=# {x≤2: f1(x)=t}: t>5:0; t=5:2 (x=−1 double root, x=2); −3<t<5:3; t=−3:2 (x=1 double, x=−2); t<−3:1.

gpt-5.title: Analyze right branch f2
gpt-5.body: For x>2, f2(x)=a(x−2)(x−b)+9 with a,b∈N. Vertex at m=(2+b)/2, minimum y_min=9−a(b−2)^2/4. Cases: (i) b≥3: R(t)=# {x>2: f2(x)=t} is t<y_min:0; t=y_min:1; y_min<t<9:2; t=9:1 (x=b); t>9:1. (ii) b=2 or b=1: R(t)=0 for t≤9 and R(t)=1 for t>9 (since x=2 not included, no t=9 solution).

gpt-5.title: Avoid infinite k (no g=3 on intervals)
gpt-5.body: Let g(t)=L(t)+R(t). If g(t)=3 on any open interval, then H(k)=g(k)+g(k−0)+g(k+0)=3g(k)=9 for all k there, giving infinitely many k, which is forbidden. Check cases: • b=1 or 2: For −3<t<5, L=3 and R=0 ⇒ g=3 on an interval ⇒ disallowed. • b≥3: If y_min<−3, then on (y_min,−3), L=1, R=2 ⇒ g=3 ⇒ disallowed. If y_min∈(−3,5), then on (−3,y_min), L=3, R=0 ⇒ g=3 ⇒ disallowed. If y_min∈(5,9), then on (−3,5), L=3, R=0 ⇒ g=3 ⇒ disallowed. Therefore the only way to avoid any open interval with g=3 is y_min=−3 with b≥3.

gpt-5.title: Verify uniqueness of k and maximize a+b
gpt-5.body: With y_min=−3 and b≥3, counts are: t<−3: g=1; −3<t<5: g=3+2=5; 5<t<9: g=0+2=2; t>9: g=1. At k=−3: g(−3−)=1, g(−3)=L(−3)+R(−3)=2+1=3, g(−3+)=5 ⇒ sum=1+3+5=9 (unique solution). Other special t (5,9) do not yield 9. Hence each candidate gives exactly one k. Maximize a+b: (48,3)→51, (12,4)→16, (3,6)→9. Maximum is 51.

grok-4-fast.title: Analyze piecewise function f(x)
grok-4-fast.body: The function f(x) is defined as a cubic polynomial p(x) = 2x^3 - 6x + 1 for x ≤ 2, and a quadratic q(x) = a(x-2)(x-b) + 9 for x > 2. Compute p(2) = 5 and q(2+) = 9, indicating a jump discontinuity at x=2 from 5 to 9. Analyze p(x): p'(x) = 6(x^2 - 1), critical points x=±1, p(-1)=5 (local max), p(1)=-3 (local min). Thus, n_left(t) = number of roots of p(x)=t for x≤2: 1 for t<-3, 2 at t=-3, 3 for -3<t<5, 2 at t=5, 0 for t>5.

grok-4-fast.title: Determine n_right(t) for x>2
grok-4-fast.body: For b≤2, q(x) ≥9 (approached as x→2+), n_right(t)=0 for t≤9, 1 for t>9. For b>2, let d=b-2≥1, m=9 - a d^2/4 <9 (minimum at vertex (2+b)/2>2). Then n_right(t): 0 for t<m, 1 at t=m, 2 for m<t<9, 1 at t=9, 1 for t>9. Since b≤2 yields no k with sum=9, assume b>2.

grok-4-fast.title: Compute sums at critical points
grok-4-fast.body: Critical points: k=-3,5,m,9. Sums: at -3 (m>-3):6; (m<-3):12; at 5 (m<5):11, (m>5):5; at 9:4. At m (m≠-3,5): 3 n_left(m) +3 (3,6,12 possible, not 9). Only possible for sum=9 if m=-3 or 5, but m=5 gives sum=8 at k=5. For m=-3: at k=-3, sum=3+1+5=9; at 5:11; at 9:4. Exactly one such k.

grok-4-fast.title: Solve for a, b satisfying m=-3
grok-4-fast.body: m=-3 implies a (b-2)^2 =48, d=b-2≥1 integer, a=48/d^2 integer. Possible: d=1 (a=48, b=3), d=2 (a=12, b=4), d=4 (a=3, b=6). a+b:51,16,9. Maximum 51, option ①.
